Text: The fool says in his heart, “There is no God.” They are corrupt, and their ways are vile; there is no one who does good.
Context: The psalmist is describing the corruption of those who deny God’s existence, highlighting their moral depravity.

Text: God looks down from heaven on the sons of men to see if there are any who understand, any who seek God.
Context: This verse shifts perspective to God, who is observing humanity, searching for righteousness.

Text: Every one of them has turned aside; together they have become corrupt; there is no one who does good, not even one.
Context: The psalmist generalizes the fallen state of mankind, emphasizing the universality of corruption.

Text: Do the workers of iniquity not know? They devour my people as though eating bread; they do not call on God.
Context: Here the psalmist is incredulous that the wicked can be so oblivious to their evil, exploiting the righteous and neglecting God.

Text: There they were, overwhelmed with dread, where there had been no fear before. For God has scattered the bones of those who encamped against you; you put them to shame, for God has rejected them.
Context: This verse speaks about the sudden terror that grips the wicked, even though there was no cause for fear, pointing out that God will ultimately defeat those who oppose Him.

Text: Oh, that salvation for Israel would come out of Zion! When God restores the fortunes of His people, let Jacob rejoice and Israel be glad!
Context: This expresses hope and anticipation for God’s deliverance of Israel and the resulting joy that will come with restoration.
